text: Thinking of updating my local box (which I use for backtesting), which may mean moving from the older to newer CPU in this comparison. <https://cpu.userbenchmark.com/Compare/Intel-Core-i7-4700MQ-vs-Intel-Core-i7-13650HX/2727vsm2049566> Any ideas how I can guage how much of a performance bump I can expect? The latter CPU is just one I've pulled from an arbitrary top of line performance laptop. I believe most of my backtesting is cpu-bound and not io-bound.

elements.text: Thinking of updating my local box (which I use for backtesting), which may mean moving from the older to newer CPU in this comparison.

Any ideas how I can guage how much of a performance bump I can expect? The latter CPU is just one I've pulled from an arbitrary top of line performance laptop. I believe most of my backtesting is cpu-bound and not io-bound.

text: Benchmarks might give you a generalised idea, but in reality to get an accurate answer you’re going to end up understanding how well your exact code maps to the CPU - cores, caches, and so on - so I think you might just have to hope for a generalised idea of improvement and test when you get it.

elements.text: Benchmarks might give you a generalised idea, but in reality to get an accurate answer you’re going to end up understanding how well
your exact code maps to the CPU - cores, caches, and so on - so I think you might just have to hope for a generalised idea of improvement and test when you get it.

text: I made the switch in the last year from a laptop with a four core 8 thread intel cpu to a i9-13980HX. My god, it's soo much faster. If you're buying it for the sake of backtesting, I'd profile your code. Try renting a big VM on the cloud and backtest if you need to. Like <@U012XF5CNPN> said, you'll never get an exact answer. But you really should know what your bottlenecks are.

elements.text: I made the switch in the last year from a laptop with a four core 8 thread intel cpu to a i9-13980HX. My god, it's soo much faster. If you're buying it for the sake of backtesting, I'd profile your code. Try renting a big VM on the cloud and backtest if you need to. Like
said, you'll never get an exact answer. But you really should know what your bottlenecks are.

text: wow <@U01DCR5PXDY> sounds almost identical to my situation. I was hoping for some high-level anecdote that would say either "yeah the speedup is insane" or "nah didn't move the needle for me". I'll check if I currently get linear speedup when utilzing (1,2,3,4) cores, and if so that should be enough evidence that my bottleneck is indeed CPU and adding more cores should result in proportional speedup (ofc assuming I don't hit some bottleneck with disk at some N of parallel processes). That's useful, thanks

text: P.S. I'm not using flumine. So my experience is based on my own code base. But I will say, very happy I made the switch.

text:
It sounds like you are looking for some rough numbers so can give you my comparisons just to get an idea.
I have a very old 4 core 8 thread i7 and a fairly old 12 core 24 thread ryzen. The ryzen is around 5-6x faster for me running the same flumine backtest.

text: <@U80AMMRKP> didn't one of the top guys here say that professionals use Linux?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: didn't one of the top guys here say that professionals use Linux?

text: macOS is a BSD unix under the hood, which I would contend, on many points is > Linux. Performance/$ the M4 is in a different class to anything you can run Linux (or Windows) on, and even if the Mach microkernel scheduler was crap and BSD sockets were in your way a bit, you’re probably going to end up still ahead than you would on a similarly priced PC, if you’re CPU bound. GPU bound, things get different.

elements.text: macOS is a BSD unix under the hood, which I would contend, on many points is > Linux. Performance/$ the M4 is in a different class to anything you can
run

Linux (or Windows) on, and even if the Mach microkernel scheduler was crap and BSD sockets were in your way a bit, you’re probably going to end up still ahead than you would on a similarly priced PC, if you’re CPU bound. GPU bound, things get different.

text: For the price, there is literally nothing on earth faster for cpu bound tasks. macOS is a long cry from Windows, but it’s not that big a leap for most people down in the terminal from Linux. I’ve been Mac only for home (and FreeBSD and Linux for servers), for about 18 years now. Never regretted it.

text: Just checked, the stats I saw were adjusting for power consumption as well. Raw performance you might be better off with Xeon or Ryzen, but your power consumption will be much higher and I think the SKU price will be higher (the Mac tested here is a $600 complete system, including RAM, storage, PSU, etc): <https://www.phoronix.com/review/apple-m4-intel-amd-linux/5|https://www.phoronix.com/review/apple-m4-intel-amd-linux/5>

text: Phew.... I hate Mac.

elements.text: Phew.... I hate Mac.

text: Under the hood, macOS is one of the best OSes out there. Open source package management via homebrew is better than anything else I've used elsewhere, everything "just works" due to vertical integration - no driver hacking - it's a solid stack. And while people say Apple is expensive, weirdly, for the new Apple Silicon stuff it's actually remarkably cheap for that performance level...

elements.text: Under the hood, macOS is one of the best OSes out there. Open source package management via homebrew is better than anything else I've used elsewhere, everything "just works" due to vertical integration - no driver hacking - it's a solid stack. And while people say Apple is expensive, weirdly, for the new Apple Silicon stuff it's actually remarkably cheap for that performance level...
